Title: No Rules Rules: Netflix and the Culture of Reinvention
Author: Reed Hastings
My Review:
I’m lucky this year; almost all the books I have read until now are close to excellent. This one has been probably the best. The book talks about the culture at Netflix. It is perhaps more helpful for a manager and executive, but I did note a couple of topics that I consider very interesting.

The first one is giving and receiving feedback. I know that it is essential, but the text let me see that it is more than necessary; it is the best way to develop your skill inside your working environment. From now on, I will ask for more candid feedback right away.

The other is the keeper test. I will try as well to apply that. I’m sure it will sound weird to my managers, but with a previous explanation, It could be beneficial.

A fun fact is that the last part of the book directly uses the techniques that I learned from the previous book that I read, “The culture Map”. That was nice indeed.

After reading this one, I have decided that the next book will re-read radical candor. I read it some years ago, and I feel like now I’ll take more from it. So, that will come next!

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/reed-hastings-erin-meyer-no-rules-rules)

Title: Super Learning: Advanced Strategies for Quicker Comprehension, Greater Retention, and Systematic Expertise
Author: Peter Hollins
My Review:
I wasn’t expecting much from this book. I have already read many books about learning methodologies and how learning works in humans. But, I enjoyed these types of books and wanted to give another take on the subject.

During the first part of the book, I thought I had made a mistake starting it. Not only I wasn’t learning anything new, but the book felt slow. Thankfully, the second half of the book is much more enjoyable. Especially chapters 4 (Make learning secondary) and 5 (Teaching to learn) are exciting and inspiring. Nothing surprising but inspiring.

In general, and in the end, there is nothing new for me in the book, but it is a fine read. It is short and to the point, and I think it would make a perfect book as a first read on the subject. If you have not read any other essay on learning, this one could be a good entry point.

See it in my blog [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/peter-hollins-super-learning)

Title: The Culture Map: Decoding How People Think, Lead, and Get Things Done Across Cultures
Author: Erin Meyer
My Review:
As a software engineer, in the last 25 years, I have worked with many other engineers worldwide, from India or Japan to EEUU or Brazil, including all around Europe. You know that people's behaviour is affected by their culture and personality, but you are never sure what is showing in every moment. Somehow that is what this book is about.

It analyzes the different cultures and parametrizes them to allow readers to know what to expect in every type of culture. It gives you tools to handle and provide feedback from and to different cultures better.

It did help me to comprehend some experiences that I had in the past and understand and interact better with my current team. Currently, I work in a multicultural team with six different cultures; learning to communicate more effectively with them is a good skill that I want to learn and practice. I was surprised how fast I could apply what I learned in the book, identify my teammates' cultural traits, and see their personalities more clearly.

Recommend read for everyone; really, it is that useful.

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/erin-meyer-the-culture-map)

Title: A Philosophy of Software Design
Author: John Ousterhout

Title: Coaching Agile Teams: A Companion for ScrumMasters, Agile Coaches, and Project Managers in Transition
Author: Lyssa Adkins
My Review:
I found this book by chance. I searched for new ways to communicate my agile ideas, and “coaching” sounds like it. And it was.

Agile is very easy to understand but hard to get, which is misleading. What is easy is the frameworks. They are very well designed and easy to grasp. You can start a team with SCRUM in a couple of Sprints if you teach them the ceremonies and their goals and how to manage springboard and backlog. But that is just the early beginning. Getting rid of all the bad habits and working as an efficient Agile team is another story entirely. It is even more complicated if your team does not “believe” in agile. Either way, they are already convinced that it will work, or they will only be when they see it. But, if they are unwilling to give it a try for real, prepare for a bumpy road.

The book is excellent if you are interested in understanding more about the Agile concepts and go deeper in how to go across explaining the concepts to your colleagues. I love when the author clarifies the differences between “Cooperation” and “Collaboration”. Most people can not differentiate both words, which is key to understanding how a teams work.

Since I’m so passionate about this subject, I wondered if I should switch careers and start coaching other teams after taking the needed courses. It is not the first time I put this question on the table. But, even though I love it, I love even more crafting software. So I’ll stay growing the way I’m doing now. But if my team wants to go beyond in their Agile path, I’m now more ready to help with that.

One last thing. Even though the book explains many exciting concepts and is well written, I do not think it is a book for somebody who wants to start with agile. The book will probably confuse you more than help you if you are new to agile. I would say it is an advance level book.

Did I say that I’m a fan of agile? :)

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/lyssa-adkins-coaching-agile-teams)

Title: The Phoenix Project: A Novel About IT, DevOps, and Helping Your Business Win
Author: Gene Kim
My Review:
Another possible approach is to create a story that mimics reality so that the reader can experiment with what happened to reach a given status. Instead of using the actual historical events, create new ones that are more suitable for a book and do not involve real characters or situations.

Books like the Phoenix Project use that approach. With an artificial history, they give context to the problems that DevOps solve while providing a theoretical introduction to the DevOps current environment. Another book with similar approach is P Lencioni “The Ideal Team Player”.

If the writing is good, this has the effect of reading a good novel. The story is engaging, and you feel hooked because you know that these problems are real, and maybe you have already experienced similar situations. I am not an expert in DevOps, but I did identify several characters with real persons in my career. Also, many conditions described in the book feel like some of my own experiences.

It is a fantastic book that could be nicely complemented with the sequel by the same author titled “The DevOps Handbook”. I plan to read it next year, and anyway, I’ll probably reread this one first at the beginning of 2022.

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/gene-kim-the-phoenix-project/)

Title: The Checklist Manifesto: How to Get Things Right
Author: Atul Gawande
My Review:
First of all, a full disclosure. I’m a huge fan of checklists. I use them every day. In fact, I start every working day with my checklist. I use a script on my computer to generate my daily checklist. It covers the essential tasks that I have to do every day and do not want to skip. It is constantly evolving and changing, but it helps me to stay in check with my responsibilities. That said, back to the book.

It is a lovely read. As you might imagine, there is not much deep new content, but it is full of good and nicely told stories. It reminds you about how important is to have a checklist to cover the basics. With that, you avoid simple errors so you can give your full attention to the complexity of your profession.

I also found brilliant the last chapters where the author talks about professionalism. I found there what is probably the best definition that I have ever read. I did take interesting notes of that chapter.

Title: The Practice of Practice

My Review:
I did enjoy this book a lot. It was exactly what I was expecting: an investigation about the practice at the instrument and out of it, taking into account science and the opinion of professional musicians of different genres and cultures.

I like the comments about the concept of practicing for different persons and the many approaches available. It event touches the effect of sleep in the practice sessions.

But the coolest part is that some of the concepts that I learned I did apply directly to my daily practice and, I am already getting benefits from it!

Author: Amy Blankson

Title: Ketones, The Fourth Fuel: Warburg to Krebs to Veech, the 250 Year Journey to Find the Fountain of Youth
Author: Travis Christofferson
My Review:
This book complements quite nicely the books from Gary Taubes. Especially from the historical point of view. “Good Calories, Bad Calories” gives many details about the history of the investigation on diets and the last century. Still, it was hard to follow due to the many subjects and characters in the book.

In contrast, this one center on the characters and with them builds a story of a century of investigation culminating on the ketones as we understand them now.

It was an enjoyable read, and I think I’ll give it another go before the end of the year.

in my [blog](https://josealobato.com/travis-christofferson-ketones-the-fourth-fuel)

Title: Overcoming Dyslexia: A New and Complete Science-Based Program for Reading Problems at Any Level
Author: Sally E. Shaywitz
My Review:
The book is a explanation of dyslexia with great detail. It covers history, detection, and actions to take to mitigate this incapacity’s effects. But it repeats a lot. Sometimes even the author excuses herself for the repetition. The book is very long, and a big part of that is the amount of repetition included for every critical topic. I do not understand why the editor did not fix that.

That said, the content of the book is excellent. I did learn many things, and it is a perfect complement to some other, more practical books.

In my blog: https://josealobato.com/sally-e-shaywitz-overcoming-dyslexia

Title: The Mindful Athlete: Secrets to Pure Performance
Author: George Mumford
My Review:
I pick up this book because I wanted to read something about athletics and performance. I was about to re-read “Endurance,” but I did prefer to try something new. Then I started to read this book and realize that it was about mindfulness associated with the sport. That was a pleasant surprise. I should have guessed it that by the title, but I just read “performance.”

The next fantastic surprise was that it talks a lot about basketball and I love it. Mindfulness and basketball in the same book, that was fun. I did learn several things in the book, and I’m now more aware of the importance of mindfulness in sports in the last 50 years.

The book is easy to read, entertaining, and informative.

Title: Acordes y desacuerdos
Author: Régis Hautière
My Review: I did not like very much the drawings but I liked the theme and the colors. Finally, I end up enjoying it all. The story is nice and well plotted and becomes a pleasant read with a happy ending. You end up with a smile. Curiously it is perfect for Valentine's day.

Title: Drive: The Surprising Truth About What Motivates Us
Author: Daniel H. Pink
My Review:
Common sense is the central theme of this book. Primarily talks about one single topic and revolves around it along the book. It is interesting, but at the same time it is very predictable, so, it does not discover anything new (at least for me). I have been lucky enough to work in all kind of companies with different management styles, so I saw by myself what works and what does not work that well.

There are some cool things, though. The idea that I enjoyed the most is how it moves long the history presenting the motivation in the frame of an “Operating System.” The beautiful thing about this approach is that it allows you to realize how we have reached a real point. I also enjoyed thinking about how my current employer applies the concepts in the book.

It is easy and recommended read.

Update:

This is the second time I read this book. Like this first time, I did enjoy the book, but it brings nothing new or helpful. I did not take any notes or gain any unique insight. So, I can not recommend this one.

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/daniel-h-pink-drive)

Title: Liquid Rules: The Delightful and Dangerous Substances That Flow Through Our Lives
Author: Mark Miodownik
My Review:
I am a math person, and I never really liked chemistry. It is a highly interesting subject, but it just did not click in me. But, in this book, I loved the author's explanations about the matter's molecules and states. I do not only learn new things but also had a lot of fun with the peculiar humor of the author.

I recommended it for a relaxed and easy read.

Now, I have a lot of respect for the ball pen and air conditioning.

Title: The Complete Guide to Fasting: Heal Your Body Through Intermittent, Alternate-Day, and Extended Fasting
Author: Jason Fung
My Review:
I have been doing intermittent fasting for more than two years already, but I never did more than 24 hours. I was Ok doing between 16 to 18 hours every day. But this book changed that. After reading it, I feel entirely informed to try doing more, and I did. The first attempt was 48 hours that I did without problems. For the last two weeks, I’m in, what the author name, the 24 hours protocol. It is intermittent fasting, including three full days a week.

I am a firm believer that fasting helps the body to heal and recover. I feel very well after 48h with just water (I did not even take my regular morning coffee). I plan to move to the 32 hours protocol in the following weeks. And when I am prepared, I’ll attempt five days fast.

My experience with fasting has been exactly as the author describes it. So I wholeheartedly recommend the book if you are interested in the subject.

For those that don’t know me, I do not need to lose weight. My BMI is 23. It is simply that I like to experiment with things that I feel could be good for me. Also, notice that my diet is low in carbs since 2017.

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/jason-fung-the-complete-guide-to-fasting)

Title: The Pragmatic Programmer: Your Journey to Mastery
Author: Andrew Hunt
My Review:
If you are a software developer, just read it and enjoy it. This kind of books reminds you of how cool is our profession.

I wanted to read this book a long time ago. It was exactly what I expected. I already know and apply most of the concepts in the book. I learned all of it by my self or by reading other books. Anyway, the books is a pleasure to read, and It will be one of the books that I will recommend to any new developers. Senior developers will not benefit from it if they are the kind of people to embrace new ideas and try them by yourself.

The one thing that I refresh with this book is the strategy to estimate everything you do. I was doing that in the past, but mistakingly, I did stop doing that. Thanks to this book, I did start doing that again. And it is fun to realize how bad I am doing estimation on my work. Whenever I have to start something, I add an estimate on my daily log and revisit the time when done with it. I do it properly for code reviews or documentation work, but poorly for coding tasks.

Title: Advanced iOS App Architecture: Real-World App Architecture in Swift
Author: Ray Wenderlich
My Review:
The book is “advance” in the way that is written. It is complex to follow, and some of the chapters look out of place. Throughout the book, they base their explanation in a fairly simple application where it is very difficult to see the solution that the architecture gives to real application problems. I understand that using and simple app is convenient, but any kind of book that is tagged as “advance” should be able to point to an existing complex open-source application where you can see it in action. It is only valid to cover only some aspects when backed by are real bug example.

I was expecting a lot from the elements sections but found that it is not better from what I’m doing right now. In fact, I see the architecture of the product I’m working right now is superior in many aspects.

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/rene-cacheaux-advanced-ios-app-architecture)

Title: The Late Show (Renée Ballard, #1; Harry Bosch Universe, #29)
Author: Michael Connelly
My Review:
Last year I read another novel from M. Connelly. I did enjoy it so much that I decided to read another this year. “The Late Show” introduces another detective and an intricate plot that makes you think and keeps you hook in the story for the whole book. It is a very entertaining novel.

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/michael-connelly-the-late-show/)

Title: Linchpin: Are You Indispensable?
Author: Seth Godin
My Review:
The concept of the book doesn’t really fancy my life philosophy. I’m more a team player than an individualist. But the book ends up being interesting. It resulted in a delightful read (listening) and the many examples that the author uses are amusing.

I did not agree with him ignoring the importance of real teamwork. In my 20+ years of experience with teams, I realize that there is nothing more powerful than a well assembly team of 5 or 7 people. They complement each other to perform like 10. But it a challenging task to build it up. It might take years, and It might never happen for some teams. He even dismissed the word “Teamwork” as a term used by bosses to manipulates employes.

Anyway, I did enjoy the book, and I would recommend it as a text to make you think about your approach to work and life.

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/seth-godin-linchpin)

Title: Untangled: Guiding Teenage Girls Through the Seven Transitions into Adulthood
Author: Lisa Damour
My Review:
I said this in my previous review of the book “Voice Lessons for Parents.” This book is like a manual for teenage parents. I learned a lot, and it helps me with my teen at home, especially at the moment of talking to her. You, like any adult, understand what is going on with her. But it is a whole different thing talking to her properly. To empathize with her at the same time that you make her respect the basic rules of your home. It is a tough balance that I was struggling to get. This book helps me with that, and at the same time gave me a lot of little tricks to be a better parent. I am grateful to the author for sharing all that.

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/lisa-damour-untangled)

Title: How Music Works
Author: David Byrne
My Review:
It sounds heartfelt. It doesn’t look like the author tries to sell you the music industry or even his music. It sounds like telling facts, always remembering that it is his point of view and experience, nothing else.

I did enjoy the read very much. It is dense and full of facts but also very informative and insightful. I did like that he talks about many topics, from music creation to the related economics.

I agree with other comments saying that you do not need to be a Talking Heads fan to enjoy the book. I did listen to Byrne music, and I can say that I do not like it. And that is OK.

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/david-byrne-how-music-works)

Title: Barking Up the Wrong Tree: The Surprising Science Behind Why Everything You Know About Success Is (Mostly) Wrong
Author: Eric Barker
My Review:
It is a lovely read, with a caveat: it is way too packed. It feels like a summary of the other many books that I have read. It doesn’t focus on addressing a topic, but touching all of them. Probably because of that, you get tired of the many references to studies (“A study from… says…”)

Despite all that, I did enjoy it, and I may give it another try later in the year*. It might be an excellent summary of concepts. Also, I did enjoy the more informal way he writes at times. Talking directly to the reader and asking us questions.

[*] I notice I say that many times lately.

See it in my blog: [josealobato.com](https://josealobato.com/eric-barker-barking-up-the-wrong-tree)

Title: The Lost Art of Listening: How Learning to Listen Can Improve Relationships
Author: Michael P. Nichols
My Review:
When I got the book, I was thinking of how someone could write a three hundred pages book about how to listen. I sounded weird, but I was interested in the topic, so I got the book. After reading “Voice Lessons for Parents,” this book seems like the perfect complement to improve in that arena. Now I can say that the book delivers.

My interest in this topic is the goal of improving my relationship with everyone around me, but especially with Julia and Pau. I want to be the best possible parent to both of them, so learning all communication mechanisms is the essential toolset for the job.

The book covers tons of scenarios, from work to family. But it does not include only the listening part but communication in general and even more the relationship that derives from those communications.

It is a bit slow, and some may say a bit repetitive at times, but I did enjoy it, and I think I learned several interesting techniques to apply. Now I just need to practice.

See it in my blog: https://josealobato.com/michael-p-nichols-phd-the-lost-art-of-listening/

Title: Voice Lessons for Parents: What to Say, How to Say it, and When to Listen
Author: Wendy Mogel
My Review:
Lately, I have been reading a lot about parents and kids. At the moment, I have a teenage daughter and a 9-year-old son. And I want to have as much information as possible on how to raise them happily.

I have listened to many parents saying that kids do not come with a "user manual." Now I know that that sentence is wrong. There are plenty of books that help on correcting the many biases we parents have. This one is probably the most useful, or practical, of those books. There is plenty of theory, but there is a lot of practical advice.

I like the fact that it is divided into girls and boys. I have both, and they are very different not only because they are different persons but because of their gender. It is surprising how the author describes my kinds when she suggests on what to expect from every gender.

I fully recommend this book.

See it in my blog: http://josealobato.com/wendy-mogel-voice-lessons-for-parents/

Title: The Untethered Soul: The Journey Beyond Yourself
Author: Michael A. Singer
My Review:
I did not understand this book. Either the message was too complicated or too simple, but I did not catch the idea. I guess that I do not see what the author means when he says, “let it go.” How do you let go of things?.

That said, I did enjoy the book. I listened to this one and was well narrated and nice to hear. I do not understand all the religious things since I’m not religious myself, but in this case, that did not bother me much.

I’m thinking about giving it another go throughout the year.

See it on my blog: https://josealobato.com/michael-singer-the-untethered-soul/

Title: The Science of Storytelling
Author: Will Storr

Title: Test-Driven Development: By Example
Author: Kent Beck

Title: How to Take Smart Notes: One Simple Technique to Boost Writing, Learning and Thinking – for Students, Academics and Nonfiction Book Writers
Author: Sönke Ahrens

Title: Endure: Mind, Body, and the Curiously Elastic Limits of Human Performance
Author: Alex  Hutchinson

Title: How to Lead When You're Not in Charge: Leveraging Influence When You Lack Authority
Author: Clay Scroggins
My Review:
It was quite violent for me all that talk about God. I was not expecting that. The performance is good, but all that message about the divine does not allow me to concentrate on the supposedly real message of the book. I did return it after listening to more than half of it.

I would have appreciated a more explicit reference of Christianity in the tittle. Some like "What God has to say about leading." That is, in fact, a sentence in the book.

Title: Run Fast: How to Beat Your Best Time Every Time
Author: Hal Higdon
My Review:
The book is long but full of small stories here and there that makes it a lovely read. There are so many stories that, at some moments, I miss the point of the section or the chapter.

Reading it I can feel a person that loves the sport, and that enjoys it every time he has the opportunity.

I liked the fact that, after explaining the science behind, he does things because “it feels good.” That is a beautiful human touch.

If you are looking for a running guide step by step, this is not the book with you. But if you are in the search for a workout plan and understand the reason behind that plan, Hal does an excellent job in this one.

Title: Product Mastery: From Good To Great Product Ownership
Author: Geoff Watts

Title: Fahrenheit 451
Author: Ray Bradbury

Title: The Scrum Fieldbook: A Master Class on Accelerating Performance, Getting Results, and Defining the Future
Author: J.J.  Sutherland

Title: Go Wild: Free Your Body and Mind from the Afflictions of Civilization
Author: John J. Ratey
My Review:
Previously this year, I read “Spark” [1]. I liked it very much and found that the author has another book. I looked at it, and it seemed very appealing. I got it last week, and I did enjoy every word probably because It confirms some of the decisions that I took since 2016, including diet, exercise, sleep, mindfulness, and more. I learned some about why I have to run more in the mountains and less on the treadmill. I fancy the idea, but I now need to find a place to do it.

Also, the structure of the book is smart. I like the fact that the authors defer their personal experiences to the end.

The only thing that I’m missing is some bits about fasting. But I’ll find this in another book.

[1] [Spark on GoodReads](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/721609.Spark)

Title: Can't Hurt Me: Master Your Mind and Defy the Odds
Author: David Goggins
My Review: The book is long. It repeats itself a lot, and the vocabulary is very poor. But I did enjoy it.

Title: Digital Minimalism: Choosing a Focused Life in a Noisy World
Author: Cal Newport
My Review: I was not expecting to enjoy this book that much. I haven’t learned anything from it, because I already did my job minimizing my social networking and electronic usage about five years ago. I do not use any social network, and my phone is a learning tool. Of course, I use it for work, but only during work hours. I did like the part where he talks about teenagers and the effect of mobiles on their lives. It is what I see every day all around me, and I mostly agree with him. If you haven’t done that digital declutter it is a very good book to start going in that direction.

Title: Talking to Strangers: What We Should Know About the People We Don’t Know
Author: Malcolm Gladwell
My Review:
Typical Gladwell. But in this one, I notice he is a bit superficial in some cases and very deep into the issue in some others. Some of the stories are very familiar to me, but that is, probably, because I read a lot of this kind of book.

One thing that I liked a lot is that this audiobook is more than a book. Some times it contains the original recordings of the protagonist in clouded, and that is a nice touch. I’ll probably listen to it again in some months.

Title: Stillness Is the Key
Author: Ryan Holiday
My Review:
I did enjoy this book. At the beginning, I was a bit disappointed. It sounded very similar to the previous books. All those references to ancient philosophers and known figures seem the same as the earlier books. It uses some of the same characters that where already mention in the other books. At some moments, I was tempted to put the book down. But, half of the book on, the tone of it changes. It becomes more direct and, what it looks to me, more practical. I liked the fact that in some chapters give immediate advice on some techniques to apply on working and getting out of bad habits.

Even though it did not discover anything new to me, I think it is a delightful read. It also reinforces the good habits that I have been practicing during the last decade.

Title: Do the Work: Overcome Resistance and Get Out of Your Own Way
Author: Steven Pressfield

Title: The War of Art: Winning the Inner Creative Battle
Author: Steven Pressfield

Title: Pastwatch: The Redemption of Christopher Columbus
Author: Orson Scott Card

Title: Ultralearning: Master Hard Skills, Outsmart the Competition, and Accelerate Your Career
Author: Scott H. Young

Title: Whole Body Barefoot: Transitioning Well to Minimal Footwear
Author: Katy Bowman

Title: Predictably Irrational: The Hidden Forces That Shape Our Decisions
Author: Dan Ariely

Title: Spark: The Revolutionary New Science of Exercise and the Brain
Author: John J. Ratey

Title: Peak Performance: Elevate Your Game, Avoid Burnout, and Thrive with the New Science of Success
Author: Brad Stulberg

Title: The Obstacle Is the Way: The Timeless Art of Turning Trials into Triumph
Author: Ryan Holiday

Title: Lost Light (Harry Bosch, #9; Harry Bosch Universe, #11)
Author: Michael Connelly

Title: Ego Is the Enemy
Author: Ryan Holiday
My Review:
It is dense, and the concept is not that easy to grasp. I end up reading most of the chapters a couple of times. The book started a bit slow, but it was catching more and more my attention as got into it. I think this is the kind of book that I’ll read several times until I got the point in my head.

I’ll be complementing this book with other converting the same concepts.

Title: How to Win Friends and Influence People
Author: Dale Carnegie

Title: Soft Skills: The Software Developer's Life Manual
Author: John Z. Sonmez
My Review:
I had mix-feeling with this book. On one side, I have enjoyed the read of the book, but on the other side, I have learned almost nothing. After twenty years professionally developing software I already know about all of the approaches in the book (with some exceptions, see below). I do not watch television since early 2000s, I had my own podcast, I use the Pomodoro Technique and have my own efficiency processes for almost everything. Almost everything in the book was a “check” for me.

Despite that, I will still recommend the book to everyone since it is an easy and pleasant read and you may learn some tricks to improve as professionals.

The is one topic that I have no investing time on it. Well, I did invest time but did not succeed, and that is all about investments. I tried, and I did not enjoy it at all.

Title: The Self-Driven Child: The Science and Sense of Giving Your Kids More Control Over Their Lives
Author: William Stixrud

Title: Radical Candor
Author: Kim Malone Scott

Title: Good to Great: Why Some Companies Make the Leap... and Others Don't
Author: James C. Collins

Title: Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs
Author: Harold Abelson

Title: It Doesn't Have to Be Crazy at Work
Author: Jason Fried

Title: Killer by Nature (an Audible Original Audiobook)
Author: Jan Smith

Title: Nonviolent Communication: A Language of Life
Author: Marshall B. Rosenberg
My Review: I did not get the book. I read it two times, but I did not understand the message. I think I understand the situations it explains, but I do not understand the solutions. And I believe that the answer some of the persons looks to me very unreal. I’m not sure whether I’m not the target audience or my environment is challenging but, even after reading the book two times I do not know how to apply the techniques the author tries to explain.

Title: Swift in Depth
Author: Tjeerd in 't Veen
My Review:
The book did meet the expectations. Sometimes while reading it I had the feeling that it was too easy, but some other chapters were quite interesting, no the material itself but way of solving a problem and the kind of issues that it explains. I found it a bit easy in general, but that also makes for a delightful read.

I end up with a bunch of new flash cards to lean and even a couple of ideas for making Katas. I make a note in my reader and may retake them when needed.

It is a perfect read for an intermediate developer to give a gentle push to your knowledge.

Title: Why We Sleep: Unlocking the Power of Sleep and Dreams
Author: Matthew Walker

Title: Practical Object-Oriented Design: An Agile Primer Using Ruby
Author: Sandi Metz
My Review:
Somehow I have recovered the will to read technical books. I stopped some time ago and only managed to read one a year. But books like this one are the ones that push you not to stop reading. I got to be honest, and I should say that I have not learned very much with this book. After so many years developing software and interacting with so many good and bad developers you reach the same conclusions that Metz is explaining in the book although I found some ideas on inheritance that are kind of new to me. Mostly a different point of view that I haven’t seen around much. I also enjoyed quite a lot the simple examples. In some cases (especially in inheritance), when you feel that the solution is good enough, she gave another twist and made it even better and more enjoyable.

In my opinion, it is the perfect book to someone that has practice OOP for a bit and want to go beyond on its knowledge.

Title: Rich Dad, Poor Dad
Author: Robert T. Kiyosaki

Title: Foundation (Foundation, #1)
Author: Isaac Asimov

Title: Sovereign
Author: Jeff Hirsch
My Review: SCI-FI book for teenagers. I did enjoy it, especially at the end. Very well narrated and the plot is sometimes messy and too fantastic but, that is how a SCI-FI book should be. I should read more of these books; they open your mind to new, unexpected things.

Title: No-Drama Discipline: The Whole-Brain Way to Calm the Chaos and Nurture Your Child's Developing Mind
Author: Daniel J. Siegel
My Review:
Impressive, I started using these techniques right away and even without thinking. They are so common sense that it is an excellent approach to discipline. Now when I’m in the street and see parent fighting with their kids, I think to myself: “That is wrong.” I highly recommend it to everyone depending on the age of your kids even if you do not have kids yet.

I can’t help but the thing on those days when we said that babies came without instructions manual. All the books that I've been reading lately tell me precisely the opposite.

Title: The Bullet Journal Method: Track the Past, Order the Present, Design the Future
Author: Ryder Carroll
My Review:
I have been using a bullet journal like approach to taking notes during my whole professional life. I love writing on my physical Journal and love even more pens, but I got to was honest with myself on the past when I decided to go digital and only leave the paper journal like a romantic tool that I use to enjoy having it one. In reality, I use it for a bit more. It is always open in my desk, and I take notes on it consistently. Lately, it is also my real diary since I write every day for ten or fifteen minutes with Pau (I like that part). But my genuine TODO part takes shape on Things.app since I implemented my “Getting Things Done” around eight years ago. It is so powerful and complete that there is no way I could do that with a Journal. I would only think about changing if it was not working, but it works.

Anyway, back to the book, it is an excellent book for most of the people, especially for those that like pen and paper and do not have a proper methodology for getting things done. I like the idea of the list and trackers. I also enjoyed a lot the little stories that gave context to the different tools offered. I recommend it for everyone as a nice and easy read.

Title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
Author: Yuval Noah Harari
My Review: Depressing. The book shows us that we are the worst thing that happened to planet earth. Our disconnection from nature is so sad.

Title: The Black Holes
Author: Borja González
My Review: I think it was not for me. I did not understand it.

Title: What Doesn't Kill Us: How Freezing Water, Extreme Altitude, and Environmental Conditioning Will Renew Our Lost Evolutionary Strength
Author: Scott Carney

Title: Fünftausend Kilometer in der Sekunde
Author: Manuele Fior
My Review: I have a word that describes perfectly this graphic novel, beautiful. The story is gorgeous, the images are beautiful, and the colors are beyond excellent. I definitely want to read more about this Italian author. It is funny how you go to sleep with a ton of different feeling after finishing a story like this. Sadness, joy, homesickness and other fills your body while you relax to get sleep. Thank you, Manuele, for this beautiful piece of work.

Title: Le Rêve De Meteor Slim
Author: Frantz Duchazeau
My Review: I saw this book in Laia's library, and cound't resist. It is a black and white graphic novel explaining the life of a bluesman in the delta around the same years of Robert Johnson's death. I notice that when I'm tired of reading a dense text, this type of books is relaxing to read. They are beautiful to look at and enjoyable to read. The story is sad, as I expected.

Title: Scrum Mastery: From Good To Great Servant-Leadership
Author: Geoff Watts
My Review:
After working for five years in a scrum development team, the book did not show me anything new, but I picked up some ideas for future works on Scrum, and that is always good. It is well structured and read. I enjoyed it very much.

The second read was even better than the first. I did learn even more and I have decided that I'll read it again next year. This book is full of wisdom and details that are needed whenever you need to apply it to a real scenario. It is, no doubt, a recommended read to anyone interested in Scrum in general.

Title: Scrum: The Art of Doing Twice the Work in Half the Time
Author: Jeff Sutherland
My Review:
I enjoyed the second read of this book. The thrilling adventures that the author explains complement perfectly with my Scrum knowledge. I’ll recommend this to every software developer — an easy and useful read.

Moved to 5 stars.

Title: The Science of Mindfulness: A Research-Based Path to Well-Being
Author: Ronald D. Siegel

Title: Deep Work: Rules for Focused Success in a Distracted World
Author: Cal Newport
My Review:
I finished this book in 2019, but I have the feeling it is one of the most entertaining books of 2018. The book is not that great in fact but, I enjoyed it a lot. Before reading It, I was already sold on the idea, since I try to apply it myself every day but It is nice that you understand how good it is for other people especially if those people are very talented at their jobs.

On the second part of the book, the author gives some tips on how to achieve deep concentration. I have to say that they are not amazing tips. None of them are useful to me. I already deleted my social media account and, since I’m a minimalist, reduce my distractions and interactions to the minimum. I haven’t watched television in the last 18 years, so I know what I’m talking about.

One sad point about the books is that the author is a College professor and talks a lot about his research but almost nothing about his students. It is a sad reality that teaching professionals do not care about their students, but that is a known reality.

Anyway, a good and easy read.

Title: Ten Arguments for Deleting Your Social Media Accounts Right Now
Author: Jaron Lanier

Title: The Five Love Languages of Children
Author: Gary Chapman

Title: Mastery
Author: Robert Greene

Title: Ruby Programming: The Well-Grounded Rubyist
Author: David A. Black

Title: Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products
Author: Nir   Eyal
My Review: Entertainment. I look to me that it uses too many social networks examples to barely support the point. It is a bit superficial for my taste, and I took much more from “The Power of Habits.” I won’t recommend or reread it.

Title: The Score Takes Care of Itself: My Philosophy of Leadership
Author: Bill   Walsh
My Review: I think it is a great book. I did not enjoy all the stories about American Football. I do not understand neither I care about it. But I love the intensity or possible the writer use. You can notice that the guy lives for that. It is his passion and, somehow his life. I think is the most intensely written book I have ever read. I first chapter written by the writer itself and the last by his son is a very nice touch. I won’t, but it is the perfect book for a manager passionate about sports. Jose Luis Vicente comes to my mind here

Title: There's No Such Thing as Bad Weather: A Scandinavian Mom's Secrets for Raising Healthy, Resilient, and Confident Kids (from Friluftsliv to Hygge)
Author: Linda Åkeson McGurk

Title: The One Thing: The Surprisingly Simple Truth Behind Extraordinary Results
Author: Gary Keller
My Review: Although the target of the book does not match my approach to life (I do not want to double or triple my income) some of the ideas I found interesting to try. The concepts in the book are simple and achievable. In fact, most of the things are already aligned with the way I do things every day. I do not think it brings me anything that I will directly benefit from thought.

Title: A Guide to the Good Life: The Ancient Art of Stoic Joy
Author: William B. Irvine

Title: The Power of Habit: Why We Do What We Do in Life and Business
Author: Charles Duhigg

Title: What the Heck Is Eos?: A Complete Guide for Employees in Companies Running on EOS
Author: Gino Wickman
My Review: This was something new for me. I have been working with teams using different processes, from the vast CMMi, or my favorite Scrum, or even nothing at all. EOS took me to a straightforward, common sense approach to do the job and go in the right direction. In its simplicity, it reminds me to GTD. It uses very few tools but the right ones for the job. I think I can efficiently work as they explain and I’m happy to be aware of its existence.

Title: Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking
Author: Malcolm Gladwell
My Review: I did enjoy the book but, in my opinion, is just some nice storytelling. I did not learn anything new. I found there nothing surprising or unique, even if the author said that several times. In other words, the books left me as I was, nothing new, nothing special, just entertainment.

Title: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck: A Counterintuitive Approach to Living a Good Life
Author: Mark Manson
My Review: A fun and easy ready. It was very  quick to go through the stories, and I have to say that some of those gave me some helpful ideas. But apart from that, I found nothing more useful to me.

Title: Good Calories, Bad Calories: Challenging the Conventional Wisdom on Diet, Weight Control, and Disease
Author: Gary Taubes
My Review:
I would not recommend this book to anyone unless you are very interested in Calories, carbohydrates, fat, etc. It is a very dense read. I even read most of the chapters two times.

Overall I do not think that it is a book for the general public. Instead, it looks to me like a history book for the people investigating or working on this matter. It provides a quite complete reference to the history of every issue covered, with names dates and locations.

And as expected, there is no conclusion; you have to make your own, even if it looks like carbohydrates are the bad guy, the essential finding is that this research field was and is a mess driven by economic interest more than by science.

I should say as well that, I have been myself under a low carbohydrates diet for the last 11 months even if I was not fat initially (81kg 177cm). I have lost 11Kg that I didn’t notice it was extra weight. All this accompanied by several blood samples in the way to check that everything was going right. It was. The next blood sample is next month.

Title: El club Dumas
Author: Arturo Pérez-Reverte

Title: Remote Pairing: Collaborative Tools for Distributed Development
Author: Joe Kutner
My Review: I enjoyed it becase it talks about geek solutions. But I'm not using most of the techniques explained.

Title: iOS Internationalization: The Complete Guide
Author: Shawn E. Larson
My Review: Easy

Title: Core Animation for Mac OS X and the iPhone
Author: Bill Dudney
My Review: Basic

Title: Core Data
Author: Marcus S. Zarra
My Review: Basic

Title: Core Data
Author: Marcus S. Zarra
My Review: Basic

Title: Tmux 2: Productive Mouse-Free Development
Author: Brian P. Hogan

Title: Tmux: Productive Mouse-Free Development
Author: Brian P. Hogan
My Review: Since then I use it every day

Title: The Sketchnote Handbook: The Illustrated Guide to Visual Note Taking
Author: Mike Rohde
My Review: A must of you like pen an paper.

Title: Tools of Titans: The Tactics, Routines, and Habits of Billionaires, Icons, and World-Class Performers
Author: Timothy Ferriss
My Review: Most of the topics where not interesting for me.

Title: Programming Ruby: The Pragmatic Programmers' Guide
Author: Dave Thomas

Title: Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software
Author: Erich Gamma
Additional Authors: Ralph Johnson, John Vlissides, Richard Helm
My Review: A nice text, but difficult to read.

Title: The Well-Grounded Rubyist
Author: David A. Black

Title: La computadora universal. De Leibniz a Turing
Author: Martin D. Davis

Title: Uncle Petros and Goldbach's Conjecture: A Novel of Mathematical Obsession
Author: Apostolos Doxiadis

Title: Clean Code: A Handbook of Agile Software Craftsmanship
Author: Robert C. Martin
My Review: Again, I did not learn a lot from this book but It certainly reinforces my coding approaches and gave me some ideas that will improve my coding. I'll probably give another read in a couple of years. I'll recommend this book to people with moderate coding experience.

Title: The Hidden Brain: How Our Unconscious Minds Elect Presidents, Control Markets, Wage Wars, and Save Our Lives
Author: Shankar Vedantam
My Review:
It is the second time I read this book, and indeed, it won't be the last. "The Hidden Brain" is still one of my favorites texts. The last time I read this book, in fact, I did not "read" it, I listen to it. At the time I was running a lot and remember not stopping running until the chapter was finished. I also remember my expressions as some of the data was discovered in the book.

All of the chapters are gold, but the last ones are just inspiring. The data giving and the reasoning around it makes me feel small and encourage me to train myself better to live in this world.

In my opinion, everyone will benefit from reading this excellent book.

Title: Getting Things Done: The Art of Stress-Free Productivity
Author: David    Allen
My Review:
I think it is the third time that I read this book and I always take something new with me. This time has not been an exception. Several chapters I have read them numerous times trying to get the best possible understanding on the writer's intention.

Now, as usual, I’ll start to polish my implementation of the methodology. Adjusting some deviation that I took over the time that does not help on getting the most of the system. I always found the method exciting and useful, and now I do not conceive of my life without it. It is an integral part of the way I do things. I thoroughly recommend it to everyone.

https://josealobato.com

Title: The Clean Coder: A Code of Conduct for Professional Programmers
Author: Robert C. Martin

Title: The Algorithm Design Manual
Author: Steven S. Skiena

Title: Software Craftsmanship
Author: Sandro Mancuso

Title: This Is Your Brain on Music: The Science of a Human Obsession
Author: Daniel J. Levitin

Title: Build Awesome Command-Line Applications in Ruby 2: Control Your Computer, Simplify Your Life
Author: David B. Copeland
My Review:
A very nice read. Simple and focus.

I did not learn many things from this book, but I enjoyed reading it since it is well thought and executed.

Title: Text Processing with Ruby: Extract Value from the Data That Surrounds You
Author: Rob Miller

Title: The List of Seven (The List of Seven, #1)
Author: Mark Frost

Title: Ender's Game (Ender's Saga, #1)
Author: Orson Scott Card

Author: J.C. Hutchins

Author: J.C. Hutchins

Author: Dan Brown

Title: Angels & Demons (Robert Langdon, #1)
Author: Dan Brown

Title: The Da Vinci Code (Robert Langdon, #2)
Author: Dan Brown

Title: The E-Myth Revisited: Why Most Small Businesses Don't Work and What to Do About It
Author: Michael E. Gerber

Title: Rapt: Attention and the Focused Life
Author: Winifred Gallagher

Title: Six Pixels of Separation: Everyone Is Connected. Connect Your Business to Everyone.
Author: Mitch Joel

Title: The Pursuit of Perfect: How to Stop Chasing Perfection and Start Living a Richer, Happier Life
Author: Tal Ben-Shahar

Author: Christopher McDougall

Title: Outliers: The Story of Success
Author: Malcolm Gladwell

Title: The Tipping Point: How Little Things Can Make a Big Difference
Author: Malcolm Gladwell

Title: Clean Architecture
Author: Robert C. Martin
My Review: Exceptional. Just one message but very clear.
